awd_abstract_narration:
The Institute for Astronomy (IfA) at the University of Hawaii will host a summer REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) site in astronomy.  With about 50 faculty members and a share of all the telescopes on Maunakea and Haleakala, the IfA offers undergraduate students a wide range of opportunities. This REU site will provide research experience and professional development training for 5-6 students on O'ahu and a cohort of 3-4 students on either Maui or the Big Island each year; along with the research training, the program will benefit society by enabling scientific collaboration and interaction between native Hawaiian and non-Hawaiian students.

Distributing students across multiple islands provides the best diversity of research opportunities: (1) IfA-Hilo carries out state-of-the-art instrumentation projects for the optical/infrared telescopes on Maunakea; (2) IfA Maui has a strong solar focus, including developing two first-light instruments for the Daniel K. Inouye Advanced Solar Telescope on Haleakala; and (3) IfA-Manoa has the largest staff and research breadth, with over 40 research faculty in areas ranging from planetary science to cosmology. In addition to a mentored research project, the professional development activities include an intensive short-course a weekly professional development in research skills at the start of the summer (on O'ahu), a weekly professional development lunch series, and visits to the observatories and nearby cultural landmarks on Maunakea (Big Island) or Haleakala (Maui).  IfA is ideally positioned to attract Native Hawaiians and Pacific Islanders into their first research experience through the REU program.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the IfA REU program is to provide undergraduate students with the opportunity to directly experience high quality scientific research in Astronomy. We achieved our goal by involving students in rigorous scientific projects that have been designed to fit the 10 weeks of the program (our program usually starts in the last week of May and ends in the first week of August). We also trained students on developing skills on scientific writing and presentation. During the past four summers, we admitted 20 female and 17 male students with close to 60% of them from small and community colleges. A total of 21 faculty participated as mentors (some participated multiple years and some took two students). The research areas included planetary dynamics, extrasolar planets, comets, instrumentation, galactic astronomy, extragalactic and cosmology, adaptive optics, astroseismology, solar physics, white dwarfs, and transient objects. At the end of each program, all students presented their results as oral presentations in a one-day symposium at the IfA. This symposium is held each year at the last day of the program and is attended by university officials including the provost, vice-chancellors for research and students’ affairs, director of the university undergraduate research program, and so on. Our students also participated in the annual campus-wide event organized by the University of Hawaii, Office of Undregraduate Research where undergraduate students from all parts of the campus present their works in the form of poster presentations. In 2020, these events were conducted virtually.

            As part of our training program, we also provided travel support for students to attend national and international conferences. Since the January 2018 meeting of the American Astronomical Society (AAS), 20 of our students have attended AAS and other related conferences including the annula meeting of the Division of Planetary Sciences, where they gave poster presentations. Eight of our 2020 students participated in the AAS virtual meeting in January 2021. In 2018 and 2019, two of our students were invited by the Council on Undergraduate Research (CUR) to present their works in CUR’s annual conferences. CUR conferences are highly prestigious and by invitation only. Participants must apply and will be selected based on the merit of their applications. CUR annual conferences cover all field of research and have only three spots for astronomy for the entire country. During the past two years, our REU students have successfully received one of these spots every year. Finally, Kaitlynn Lilly, one of our 2019 REU students attended the 2020 Emerging Researchers National Conference in STEM (ERN 2020) where her oral presentation received the most prestigious national award for the best undergraduate research presentation in physical sciences.

            Our current REU funding has resulted in 4 peer reviewed publications by our REU students (Meech et al. including REU student Haynes S., 2017; Tucker et al. including REU student Rowan, D., 2018; Rowan et al. 2019; Minsley et al. 2020).
